EthosEnergy Group has instituted a Risk Management Program for the Central Valley Finaince Authority Carson Ice-Gen (CVFA) which it operates and maintains under contract to the Sacramento Metropolitan Utility District (SMUD), in accordance with Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Program regulations at 40 CFR Part 68 and California Health & Safety Code (H&SC) Division 20, Chapter 6.95, Article 2, Section 25534(b)(1) and California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP). The Risk Management Program identifies the equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with Regulated Substances (RS's) handled at this facility in excess of Federal threshold quantities; describes the structured assessment of hazards which was conducted to assess possible effects on employees and offsite public and environmental receptors; provides the results of an offsite consequences analysis; defines a prevention program, emergency response program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probability and magnitude of accidental releases of RS's; and establishes a schedule and responsibilities for implementation of mitigation measures and auditing of program elements.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is being filed with the USEPA and Sacramento County Environmental Management Department as required by CalARP regulations in order to report the elements of the current Risk Management Program and to describe further measures planned to mitigate or prevent accidental releases of RS's. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

EthosEnergy Group is the contract operator of a cogeneration facility, CVFA Carson Ice-Gen, located at 8580 Laguna Station Rd., Elk Grove, CA in Sacramento County, owned by Central Valley Finance Authority.  Anhydrous ammonia is used for selective catalytic reduction of nitrogen oxides in the gas turbine exhaust.  This RS is handled in quantities greater than its

Federal threshold quantity.  



The facility is located in an area directly South of Sacramento Regional Wastewater Treatment Plant surrounded by a wildlife habitat.  There are 8 full-time employees at this site.  Anhydrous ammonia is received in bulk and charged into a 12,000 gallon capacity bulk storage tank. Administrative controls based on RAGAGEPs limit the maximum amount of the tank to 10,800 gallons. Ammonia vapor is injected into each of the two gas turbine exhaust ducts and the auxiliary boiler unit where it dissociates into free nitrogen and hydrogen under high temperature conditions and then re-combines with nitrogen oxides and oxygen under the influence of a catalyst to produce nitrogen gas and water vapor. The feed rate of ammonia is adjusted automatically, based on continuous emission monitors in the exhaust gas.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is the policy of EthosEnergy Group that the receipt, storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia at its facility be done in a manner which meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia to the atmosphere, in order to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public, and the environment. In order to accomplish this goal, EthosEnergy Group has gathered safety information on anhydrous ammonia and on the process, equipment and procedures involving anhydrous ammonia; performed a structured assessment of hazards of the process and external events which might affect the process; performed an offsite consequences analysis of defined release scenarios; established a written program for prevention and mitigation of accidental releases; and established a written emergency response program coordinated with emergency response agencies.

General Accidental Release Prevention Programs

General accidental release prevention programs instituted by EthosEnergy Group are categorized as administrative (management) progra

ms; procedures, training, and engineering controls; and

emergency response programs. EthosEnergy Group has instituted a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program meeting OSHA requirements at 29 CFR 1910.119 (8 CCR 5189) covering its selective catalytic reduction process. This constitutes the general accidental release prevention program elements required for both the RMP and PSM for EthosEnergy Group's operations.

Chemical-Specific Release Prevention Steps

Release prevention steps specific to anhydrous ammonia have been identified and implemented. These include, among other things, installation of an additional emergency shower and eyewash station for the auxiliary boiler, and the creation of numerous equipment-specific operation procedures required for the introduction of new equipment.  



Long term maintenance is ongoing at the facility with the bulk ammonia tank being taken out of service for approximately 1 week for inspection and maintenance.

Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidents involving anhydrous ammonia at this facility within the past five years resulting in injuries or offsite consequences.

Emergency Response Program

EthosEnergy Group's Emergency Response Program applicable to anhydrous ammonia has been coordinated with Sacramento County Environmental Management Department, Consumes Fire and Sacramento City Fire Special Operations Division (HazMat)  It consists of notification of the public agency assigned responsibility for First Response to hazardous materials release emergencies. First Responders have participated with CVFA Carson Ice-Gen personnel in response drills.

Additional drills emergency response drills, such as active shooter, have been conducted as in 2019 and 2020.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the Hazard Reviews and program audits prior to 2020 which EthosEnergy Group committed to accomplish have been completed.  The recommendations made in 2020 ar

e expected to be completed within approximately 12 months. Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys, or as a result of audit activities, will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.
